460.
Simon Hooper
, was indicted for
stealing one pewter dish, val. 2 s. one pewter plate, val. 1 s. one smoothing iron, val. 6 d. the goods of
Jane Daniels
, June 19 .

Jane Daniels
. I live in Perkins's rents, Westminster
, the prisoner lodged in my house, the 19th of June I lost these things, I was out, and my two women that were at work stopp'd him with the things. When he was taken he said he took them; before the justice he owned taking the things, and was very sorry for it, and would pay me for them.
Cross examined.
Q. Did not you give him them to pawn?
Daniels. I never in my life gave him any thing to pawn.

Eliz. Cook. I saw the prisoner take the pewter dish and plate from off the chest of drawers, I followed him, he threatned me; he had been in the room about half an hour, I was sitting at my work, said I, Simon don't take the things away.
Q. Did he take them away?
Cook. Yes, he did.
Cross examined.
Q. What was he doing all the time he was in the room?
Cook. He might walk up or down stairs, I cannot say to that.
Q. Did not you take them from the chest of drawers yourself?
Cook. No, I did not; all that I can say is he stole them.
Q. When was this?
Cook. This was the 19th of June.
Q. Did you tell the prosecutor the next day where the things were?
Cook. No, I did not.
Q. How long have you been acquainted with the prisoner?
Cook. About two years.

Ann Griffin
. I have lived in the house going on two years. On the 19th of June I saw the prisoner take the flat iron out of the house, out of a one pair of stairs room, I desired him to let it alone, and he would not.
Cross examined.
Q. Was you there when the pewter was lost?
Griffin. I was not.
Q. Why did not you stop him when he would carry it away?
Griffin. What is a woman in a man's hands?
Q. When did you see Mrs. Daniels after this?
Griffin. Not till the next morning.
Q. Did you hear any thing of his stealing the pewter then?
Griffin. No, I did not, Mrs. Daniels did not tell me of it till the flat iron was lost.

Prisoners defence. My landlady the Prosecutrix went to Chelsea along with me on the Monday before; she had beer and victuals, which I was charged 4 s. and 6 d. for; she wanted punch, and on the Tuesday she wanted to go again. I did not come home till Wednesday morning; said she, I will do for you, for I will swear a robbery against you; for what, said I? for a pewter-dish, a plate, and flat-iron, said she; said I, I know nothing about them. She had given me these things several times to pawn.
For the Prisoner.

John Deleney
. I have known the Prisoner these twelve years, he is an honest man, he was a soldier; has served abroad and is disabled, and is now a pensioner. This Prosecutor was in my house the Monday before this; she then told me the Prisoner was as honest a fellow as any in the world, saying, he often takes things of me to carry out to pawn, and he always brings them home again.

Thomas Peacock
. I have known him about two years; he is a very honest man.

George Gardner
. I have known him about two years and have imployed him to carry out coals; he is a very honest man, he has taken money for me and brought it home very punctually.
Acq .
